body:
I mean like nostalgic stuff like old software and other media that got bought out and morphed by woke companies into tracking infested woke pieces of the political machine. Would how would you feel about a community funded effort to buy back and clean up some of the damage done to them, whether it involves open sourcing or some other modification to better protect this kind of stuff? 

I just though of it when I realized how many open source clones exist of the game "Minecraft" that attempt to bring back the essence of the original. But lets face it, no matter how amazing some of the devs are you just can't replace something so iconic and ingrained into pop-culture. 

So I just had a random insane idea and Ruqqus seemed like just the kind of people who'd be interested; A community funded organization with the goal of buy back media that's important/ingrained in online culture and opening it into the public domain or something along those line.

I just though of it when I realized how many open source clones exist of the game "Minecraft" that attempt to bring back the essence of the original. But lets face it, no matter how amazing some of the devs are you just can't replace something so iconic and ingrained into pop-culture.

So I just had a random insane idea and Ruqqus seemed like just the kind of people who'd be interested; A community funded organization with the goal of buy back media that's important/ingrained in online culture and opening it into the public domain or something along those line.

title: How insane of an idea would it be to create a community fund to buy back all the stolen ips?

body:
What is with Zoomers and believing intellectual property rights are legitimate?

If you want to clean up the damage done to your favorite franchise, go re-edit it, upload it, share it.
body_html:
What is with Zoomers and believing intellectual property rights are legitimate?

body:
The main issues with a lot of this is 
1: Lawyers, I don't think people wanna get dicked down by some corporate ass.
2: For software a lot if proprietary and thus can't exactly be re-edited very easily unless you undertake the very long process of de-compiling binaries and even then you may be missing some asset.
body_html: The main issues with a lot of this is 1: Lawyers, I don't think people wanna get dicked down by some corporate ass. 2: For software a lot if proprietary and thus can't exactly be re-edited very easily unless you undertake the very long process of de-compiling binaries and even then you may be missing some asset.

body: Intellectual Property Rights *are* legitimate. They are works of the mind and just as legitimate as works of the hand and you don't get to pretend their not just because you have no original thoughts.
body_html: Intellectual Property Rights are legitimate. They are works of the mind and just as legitimate as works of the hand and you don't get to pretend their not just because you have no original thoughts.

body:
"You can't make a fanfilm using characters I invented! I didn't want Princess Derpy-Derp to marry Prince Hurr in my original vision! That is illegal to write a story that says they did".

Retarded.

body:
It'd be easier to get rid of IP rights altogether than do this. Unfortunately that's about as likely as becoming ancap.

The fundamental problem is that such harsh ip laws are a requirement of several international organizations, which countries can't just back out of without serious implications. Banning of "Derivative works" and the like as well as ultra lengthy terms didn't used to happen in the US until the international organizations mandated it. Plus Disney is in bed with the deep state and they'll *never* stop with the Mickey Mouse curve, nor the expanding of how much control ip holders have; at this point it's not even legal to *think* about something without permission.
body_html:
It'd be easier to get rid of IP rights altogether than do this. Unfortunately that's about as likely as becoming ancap.

The fundamental problem is that such harsh ip laws are a requirement of several international organizations, which countries can't just back out of without serious implications. Banning of "Derivative works" and the like as well as ultra lengthy terms didn't used to happen in the US until the international organizations mandated it. Plus Disney is in bed with the deep state and they'll never stop with the Mickey Mouse curve, nor the expanding of how much control ip holders have; at this point it's not even legal to think about something without permission.
